Chimpanzees have an innate trait to impulively act out or teach other apes social behavior as a survival mechanism. Treating other animals is a way they use to teach another animals a social behavior that they may think helps them survive long term.

We are only now beginning to investigate the natural antibiotics and other signalling chemicals that ants can produce endogenously. Worker ants leave pheromone trails as they search for food and can change the chemicals when they discover a source in order to alert other ants to follow that trail to carry more food back to the colony. They also have the ability to coat their bodies in specific chemicals and hormones based on pathogens they have been exposed to.

There is evidence of "prehistoric" peoples using poultices on wounds. It could either be something they discovered over generations of trial and error, or they may have learned this behavior by observing human behavior.

The chimpanzee behavior is very strange. There's no benefit to putting an insect into a wound, if anything it would introduce disease/ germs into the wound. It seems to me to be some sort of "warding off" activity, a type of superstitious activity. They've all witnessed how flying insects are attracted to dead animals, perhaps in their mind they feel by catching and subduing an insect, putting it on the wound and releasing it, this will protect  the wounded chimp from death, and hasten it's healing. Perhaps this activity gives them a sense of control?

Two things about the chimps blew my mind:
1. In one instance, three other chimps observed a mother caring for her adolescent son: the wounded chimp's older sister, a female group member, and a male group member who was observed having his own wounds treated by others both before and after the event he observed. There is a paper out there from ~2020 proposing that spoken language evolved as a way to better communicate regarding tool fabrication and usage. It sounds so similar and plausible to me. My mind blew because it made me ask questions about what is human nature. How hard is it for humans to help one another and get along? How natural is that behavior?

2. Is it unreasonable to imagine that there is a significant probability that at least some of the wisdom of ancient natural medicines that we know work (willow and aspirin, for example) have been passed down from pre-human ancestors? Mind blown. There is a school of thought that the mix of annual plants (so-called weeds) that dominate in a particular area in a given season present preventive health and nutrition properties appropriate for the current environment. It's not a stretch. I observed on my small farm in the fall of 2019 a whole acre covered by a foot-high plant I couldn't remember seeing before, copper leaf, and a strong than typical establishment of mullein, both of which have applications for respiratory illnesses.

Now, THAT'S a leap, I know, but compared to the cumulative harm of ~100 years of massive, indiscriminate inundation of the population with pharmaceuticals treating symptoms and not causes, choosing natural methods more and more is going to come closer to giving us the outcomes we must all certainly be hoping for, namely, always moving toward a sustainable approach to managing nearly 8 billion humans. 🙂

Pro social behavior is not without reward, doing it out of empathy out of the blue. Empathy developed for a reason. Is same as why we feel uneasy about foreigners or about people who are different or how we act about people who are manipulative or don't feel emotion, criminals, bullies, cheaters and whatnot. There is a place for everything, it's better to have a chain of command than a bunch of people assuming a leadership position, but also diversity of opinion is important too. So, socially we tend to prefer democracy but in case of dangers, a war or whatever, the army needs strict rules and orders are to be executed not debated. Hence why there are frictions between societies that are more free with societies that are ruled in a more authoritarian way. There are pro's and con's for both approaches and neither is the best one, otherwise the "debate" of evolution would had been finished already.
So, similarly, other animals develop social inclinations because there is a personal gain. I help you now because i want your help later if it needs be. So not empathy, rather more likely fear, survival instinct.
